text: Psalm 11
Confidence in Yahweh’s Righteousness
For the \add music\add* director. Of David.\f + \fr Ps 11 \ft The Hebrew Bible counts the superscription as the first verse of the psalm \f*
In Yahweh I have taken refuge;
how can you say to my soul,
“Flee to your mountain \add like\add* a bird”?
For look: The wicked ⸤string the bow⸥.\f + \fr 11:2 \ft Literally “tread the bow,” that is, placing the foot on the bow to bend and string it \f*
They have fitted their arrow to \add the\add* string,
to shoot from \add the\add* darkness
at the upright of heart.
When the foundations are destroyed
what can \add the\add* righteous do?\f + \fr 11:3 \ft Or “what has the righteous done” \f*
Yahweh \add is\add* in his holy temple;
Yahweh \add is\add* in the heavens \add on\add* his throne.
His eyelids see;
they test \add the\add* children of humankind.
Yahweh tests \add the\add* righteous,
but \add the\add* wicked and \add the\add* lover of violence
his soul hates.
He will rain coals\f + \fr 11:6 \ft According to Symmachus (compare also \fqa Targum Psalms \ft ) a form slightly different from the MT’s “snares” \f* on \add the\add* wicked.
Burning sulfur and scorching wind
\add will be\add* the portion of their cup.
For Yahweh \add is\add* righteous;
he loves righteous deeds.
\add The\add* upright shall see his face.
